features.popup:
Vasquez Rocks (CA-LAn-363/375)

Tataviam Â· Tataviam occupation from ~450 CE to Spanish missionization (~1797). Pictographs likely 500-1200 CE.
Rock Surface: Vasquez Formation sandstone â€” tilted alluvial sedimentary beds uplifted by San Andreas Fault activity. Sheets and slabs of varying thickness provide natural cavities for sheltered painting.
Colors & Pigments: Red (hematite ochre), black (charcoal/manganese), white (gypsum/clay). Small-scale paintings.
Style: Incised petroglyphs on red-ochred sandstone surfaces AND painted pictographs. Two distinct techniques at the same site. Paintings in small cavities in tilted sandstone sheets.
Motifs: Sun disks, centipedes, snakes, bug-like motifs very similar to Chumash. Bilaterally symmetrical designs outlined with contrasting colors. Tiny dots. Round-headed anthropomorphs with headdresses, forked-stick figures. Plant-like form possibly representing Datura blossom.
Who Made It: Tataviam (Alliklik) â€” Takic Uto-Aztecan speakers. Named 'people facing the sun' by Kitanemuk neighbors. Some paintings could be mistaken for Chumash if seen out of geographic context (King 1981:41).
Meaning: Shamanic/ceremonial. The Datura blossom motif suggests vision quest imagery from Jimsonweed ceremonies shared with Chumash. The site is near the major Tataviam village of Mapipinga.
Style Correlates: Closest to Chumash (especially VentureÃ±o Chumash) style and scale; also Kawaiisu.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; King 1981; Hudson 1982; Knight (PCAS)

Kawaiisu Monolith Site (CA-Ker-93)

Kawaiisu Â· Kawaiisu occupation 2,000+ years. Tomo-Kahni village site nearby occupied for millennia. Pictographs likely 500-1500 CE. Rock carvings at some sites may predate Kawaiisu presence.
Rock Surface: Granite boulders and bedrock shelters in the Tehachapi Mountains â€” crystalline igneous rock with rough surfaces that may explain small painting scale.
Colors & Pigments: Red, black, white, yellow, PLUS unique earth-green pigment. Five-color palette is exceptional.
Style: Small-scale paintings on very rough granite boulder surfaces. Designs feature outlining of one color with another. Unique shade of green pigment not found at any other sites in region.
Motifs: Split-headed figures, pelts, snake with dots, bear(?) paw, figure made with dashes, pectoral/lunate design, linked circles, bug-like forms. One motif resembles Chumash paintings at Hurricane Deck (CA-SBa-1632).
Who Made It: Kawaiisu (NuwÃ¤) â€” Southern Numic Uto-Aztecan speakers. 'The People.' Peaceful hunter-gatherers of the Tehachapi Mountains between the Mojave Desert and San Joaquin Valley.
Meaning: Shamanic vision quest imagery. Kawaiisu legend says touching pictographs can cause blindness. The 'Teddy Bear' figure at CA-Ker-508 is linked to mythological stories. Pictographs seen as living and constantly changing by Kawaiisu people.
Style Correlates: Shares elements with Yokuts (linked circles, split-heads, lunate forms), Chumash (bug-like forms, outlining), AND TÃ¼batulabal (rainbow/curved lines, bear paws).
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Sutton 1982; Zigmond 1980; CA State Parks Tomo-Kahni

Teddy Bear Cave (CA-Ker-508)

Kawaiisu Â· Estimated 500-1500 CE based on artifact associations.
Rock Surface: Granite rock shelter in the Tehachapi Mountains.
Colors & Pigments: Red, black, white.
Style: Small shelter with paintings on ceiling and walls. Red snake figure on ceiling, anthropomorphic 'Teddy Bear' figure, bighorn sheep, bug-like elements.
Motifs: Long red snake, 'Teddy Bear' anthropomorph (possibly supernatural being from Kawaiisu mythology), devil anthropomorph, turtle/bug element, bighorn sheep â€” one of few representational sheep in the region.
Who Made It: Kawaiisu (NuwÃ¤). Mark Q. Sutton (1982) connected the Teddy Bear motif to specific Kawaiisu mythological narratives.
Meaning: Linked to Kawaiisu creation/mythological stories. Sutton documented connections between the 'Teddy Bear' image and stories about supernatural beings. Site also used for storage (storage pits found archaeologically).
Style Correlates: Snake and bug elements connect to broader south-central California pictograph tradition.
Sources: Sutton 1982 (JCGBA); Lee & Hyder 1991

TÃ¼batulabal Site, Lake Isabella (CA-Ker-17)

TÃ¼batulabal Â· TÃ¼batulabal territory occupied for thousands of years. Rock art sites estimated 500-1500 CE. Harper-Slaboszewicz (1982) suggests some motifs at CA-Ker-17 may indicate winter solstice observance.
Rock Surface: Granite boulders and rock shelters in the southern Sierra Nevada foothills near Lake Isabella. The Kern River canyon provided abundant granite surfaces.
Colors & Pigments: Red (hematite), white (gypsum/clay). Black less common. Large-scale application.
Style: Large-scale paintings approaching Yokuts size. Mostly abstract with few representational forms. Red and white colors dominant. Sites more than 5 km west of Sierra Nevada crest conform to TÃ¼batulabal pattern.
Motifs: Pelts, sun disk, split-headed figures, bear(?) paw, vertical snake(?), curved rainbow-like lines similar to Kawaiisu and Vasquez Rocks. Possible ring-tailed cat shown in profile â€” the most unusual motif. Fork-headed figures. Possible solstice ceremony markers.
Who Made It: TÃ¼batulabal â€” a language isolate within the Uto-Aztecan family (its own branch). The only people who spoke this unique language. Lived along the Kern River from Lake Isabella to the crest of the southern Sierra.
Meaning: Ceremonial/astronomical. The possible solstice markers suggest calendrical use alongside shamanic imagery. Correlations with Western Mono paintings noted beyond the study area.
Style Correlates: Closest to Yokuts (large scale, pelts, fork-headed figures) and Kawaiisu (rainbow curves, bear paws). Also shares snake motifs and outlined anthropomorphic heads with Tataviam.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Moratto 1984; Schiffman 1977; Harper-Slaboszewicz 1982

Tule River Painted Rock (CA-Tul-19)

Yokuts Â· Clewlow (1978) estimated paintings ~500 CE, possibly as old as 1 CE or as young as 1200 CE. Village archaeologically occupied ~500 years ago. Pictographs likely 500-1000 years old.
Rock Surface: Granite rock shelter â€” an immense boulder (20 feet thick, 30 feet long) naturally broken to create a passage. Adjacent to the Tule River with bedrock mortars, pitted boulders, and village midden. Sierra Nevada foothill granite.
Colors & Pigments: Red (hematite ochre from valley deposits), black (charcoal/clay mix), white (earthy mineral), yellow (ocherous clay). Four-color polychrome palette.
Style: ENORMOUS paintings â€” some of the largest pictographs in California. Broad outlines, vivid polychrome panels. Yellow and red dashes nearly cover one panel. Painted on ceiling and walls of granite rock shelter.
Motifs: The famous Hairy Man (Mayak Datat) â€” a 2.6m tall red/black/white figure with long hair and weeping eyes, part of a family group with mother and child. Also: coyote, beaver, bear, frog, caterpillar, centipede, eagle, condor, lizard, split-headed humans, 'Big Foot' anthropomorph, concentric circles, grids, parallel lines.
Who Made It: Yokuts â€” Wukchumni or Yowlumne bands, Penutian language speakers. The Tule River Tribe today is a mix of Yokuts, Monache (Mono), and TÃ¼batulabal ancestry. The Hairy Man tradition is shared across Penutian-speaking groups.
Meaning: Creation story imagery. The Hairy Man pictograph illustrates Yokuts creation narratives where various animals (including Hairy Man) created People. Hairy Man is sad because he was told to leave humans alone. Yokuts stories describe Hairy Man as a nocturnal forest creature who whistles to lure people. Site is both sacred ceremonial space and village center.
Style Correlates: Animal figures frequently outlined with white â€” almost identical to Santa Barbara/Chumash figures. Insect figures same type as Chumash. Ghost-like figures, large scale, and yellow pigment are distinctively Yokuts.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Strain 2012 (ISU); Latta 1949; Clewlow 1978; Hoffman 1882; Merriam 1903

Rocky Hill Site (CA-Tul-63)

Yokuts Â· Estimated 500-1500 CE. Grant (1981:22) noted affinity with TÃ¼batulabal paintings.
Rock Surface: Granite boulders in the Sierra Nevada foothills of Tulare County.
Colors & Pigments: Red, black, white, yellow.
Style: Large-scale polychrome paintings. Pelt-like figures, multi-legged creatures, centipedes. Features similar to both TÃ¼batulabal and Chumash elements.
Motifs: Pelt-like figures, centipedes, lizards, concentric circles, parallel lines, multi-legged creatures, split-headed humans. Large snake forms.
Who Made It: Yokuts â€” Southern Valley or Foothill Yokuts bands. Grant described these as 'featureless pelt forms, abstracts similar to Great Basin styles, centipedes, concentric circles, and grids.'
Meaning: Ceremonial/shamanic. Large sites near major Yokuts villages and along well-traveled trails.
Style Correlates: Affinity with TÃ¼batulabal patterns. Abstracts similar to Great Basin styles.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Grant 1981

Yokuts Snake Panel (CA-Tul-32)

Yokuts Â· Estimated 500-1500 CE.
Rock Surface: Granite rock surfaces in the Sierra Nevada foothills.
Colors & Pigments: Red, black, white, yellow.
Style: Large snake forms crossing entire panels, ghost-like figures, and a curious abstract form that may be anthropomorphic.
Motifs: Large snakes, ghost-like figures, abstract multi-line forms with split-head elements. Possible beaver-with-paddle motif (unique to Yokuts).
Who Made It: Yokuts â€” Foothill Yokuts bands.
Meaning: Shamanic imagery. The snake is a universal motif across all six tribal groups in the region, suggesting shared symbolic significance possibly related to Datura visions.
Style Correlates: Snake motifs shared with all five other tribal traditions in the region.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991

Tule River Polychrome Panel (CA-Tul-93)

Yokuts Â· Estimated 500-1500 CE.
Rock Surface: Granite rock shelter along the Tule River.
Colors & Pigments: Predominantly yellow and red dashes â€” extensive use of yellow pigment is distinctly Yokuts.
Style: Notable for yellow and red dashes of color that nearly cover one entire panel â€” creating a dense, vibrant visual effect unique among all sites.
Motifs: Dense fields of yellow and red dashes, overlaid with figures. One of the most colorful panels in the region.
Who Made It: Yokuts â€” Wukchumni or Yowlumne bands.
Meaning: The intensive use of color may represent Datura-vision imagery â€” hallucinogenic experiences often described as involving brilliant colors and geometric patterns.
Style Correlates: Yellow pigment intensity is distinctly Yokuts â€” no other group in the study used yellow so extensively.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991

Painted Rock, Carrizo Plain (CA-SLO-79)

Chumash/Yokuts shared Â· 3,000-4,000+ years of use. Pictographs span multiple periods. Still used for ceremonies by indigenous communities today.
Rock Surface: Marine sandstone â€” a smooth horseshoe-shaped formation of Miocene-age marine sedimentary rock rising from the Carrizo Plain. The protected interior alcove provides ideal conditions for paint preservation. Elevation 1,900 feet.
Colors & Pigments: Red (hematite), black (charcoal), white (yucca-based pigments), some yellow, green, and blue. Applied with rodent-tail hair brushes or finger painting.
Style: THE BORDERLINE SITE â€” both Chumash and Yokuts artists painted here, each maintaining their own distinct style. Horseshoe-shaped marine sandstone formation, 250 feet across and 45 feet tall. Interior alcove covered with pictographs spanning 3,000-4,000 years.
Motifs: CHUMASH panels: small scale, fine lines, tiny dots, mandalas, bifurcated forms, elaborate polychrome. YOKUTS panels: large scale, broad outlines, pelt-like figures resembling those from Tulare area. In some cases, Chumash-style panels sit directly adjacent to Yokuts-style panels. A Chumash painting high in a notch: small, fine lines, tiny dots, mandala. Nearby Yokuts figures: broad lines, larger, shapes typical of Tulare.
Who Made It: Chumash, Yokuts, and possibly Salinan peoples. Lee & Hyder reject the idea that painting originated among Yokuts and diffused to Chumash. Instead, both traditions developed independently and converged here because the Carrizo Plain was open territory.
Meaning: Sacred ceremonial site used by multiple peoples. The Temblor Range along the Chumash-Yokuts border was open territory where people traded, intermarried, and shared group ceremonials and hunts. Shamanic/Datura ritual imagery. Still actively used for ceremonies â€” site closed March-May except guided tours.
Style Correlates: The proof case for Lee & Hyder's thesis: rock art style as cultural communication. Two strong painting styles came together, overlapped, but each maintained its own identity.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Grant 1965, 1978; Hyder et al. 1986; BLM Carrizo Plain

Sierra Madre Ridge Sites (CA-SLO-100)

Chumash Â· Radiocarbon on Santa Barbara area pictograph pigment: 'not over 2,000 years old' (Grant). Most elaborate paintings likely 500-1500 CE. Swordfish Cave: three periods including ~3,550 years ago.
Rock Surface: Sandstone formations in the Sierra Madre Mountains south of the Carrizo Plain. The Santa Barbara region's Chumash sites are primarily in sandstone caves and shelters in the mountains.
Colors & Pigments: Red, black, white. Yellow rare. One site (CA-Ker-77) has blue-green pigment (possibly azurite/malachite or Mission-era introduced pigment).
Style: Purely Chumash style â€” no intrusive elements. Paintings range from simple to complex, from plain red or black to polychrome. Tiny figures with dot embellishments, mandalas, bifurcated elements. Free-floating, little superposition.
Motifs: Mandalas, sun disks, pelts, bug-like forms with antennae and fancy tails, dots, lizards, split-headed figures. The 'aquatic motif' is unique to Chumash. Designs placed in small cavities in rock.
Who Made It: Chumash â€” the most complex body of rock art of any group in the study. Shamans (priests/ritual specialists) are thought to have created paintings to influence supernatural beings. Chumash paint was only allowed to be traded by shamans.
Meaning: Religious/astronomical. Chumash rock art may depict cosmological concepts, vision quest imagery, solstice/equinox markers, mythic figures, and abstract concepts. Painted Cave near Santa Barbara may record a 1677 solar eclipse. Pedro Ygnacio learned from elders that circular designs represented tomols (canoes) taking souls to Shimilaqsha (afterworld), and centipede-like figures illustrated the cause of death.
Style Correlates: Closest correlate is Yokuts â€” the only other group with similar cultural complexity. Chumash style is the most distinctive: bilateral symmetry, meticulous detail, fine-line precision, tiny dots.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Grant 1965; Lee 1979, 1984; Hyder 1989; SB Museum of Natural History

Chumash Painted Cave (Alaxuluxen)

Chumash Â· Ceremonies from at least 1600s, but paintings span centuries and possibly millennia. Four styles identified from oldest (charcoal cross-hatching) to newest (elaborate polychrome). Ceremonial use discontinued ~1700s with Spanish contact.
Rock Surface: Sandstone cave â€” towering sandstone boulders in the Santa Ynez Mountains. Miocene-age marine sandstone with smooth interior surfaces ideal for painting.
Colors & Pigments: Red ochre, black charcoal, glistening white, with multiple layered styles: Style I (charcoal only, narrow lines); Style II (thick red ochre geometrics); Style III (complex polychrome imagery â€” majority); Style IV (most recent, fine detail).
Style: Among the finest Chumash rock art. Small sandstone cave with ceiling covered in elaborate polychrome paintings. Four identified painting styles showing evolution over centuries.
Motifs: Circular mandalas (possibly representing tomols/canoes to afterworld), anthropomorphs with outstretched arms, black-and-white banded centipedes, cross-hatching, celestial symbols. Possible 1677 solar eclipse depiction.
Who Made It: BarbareÃ±o Chumash. Population over 15,000 before European contact. The cave sits along a major trail from the capital city Syukhtun (Santa Barbara) over San Marcos Pass. Named 'Alaxuluxen' by Chumash elder Ernestine Ygnacio-De Soto's great-great grandmother Maria Ygnacio.
Meaning: Sacred ceremonial site. Meanings passed down through generations but largely disrupted by 300 years of colonization. Elder Ernestine Ygnacio-De Soto says the culture and language are 'sleeping, not lost.' Great-uncle Pedro Ygnacio learned that paintings represented tomols carrying souls to the afterworld, with centipedes illustrating cause of death. Now a State Historic Park (est. 1976) â€” NRHP listed 1972.
Style Correlates: Quintessential Chumash style â€” the benchmark against which other traditions are compared.
Sources: CyArk 3D documentation; CA State Parks; Archaeology Magazine 2024; Grant 1965

Hurricane Deck (CA-SBa-1632)

Chumash Â· Likely 500-1500 CE.
Rock Surface: Sandstone formations in the San Rafael Mountains, Cuyama Valley region.
Colors & Pigments: Red, black, white.
Style: Remote Chumash site in the San Rafael Mountains. Features dashes-formed designs that share similarities with Kawaiisu paintings at CA-Ker-93.
Motifs: Designs formed by red dashes, elaborate geometric forms. One of the sites showing connections between Chumash and Kawaiisu artistic traditions.
Who Made It: Chumash â€” interior mountain bands. Grant recorded 41 painted rock art sites in the Cuyama Valley region where the Sisquoc River flows between the San Rafael and Sierra Madre Mountains.
Meaning: Shamanic/ceremonial. Located in the highest parts of mountainous Chumash territory.
Style Correlates: Dash-formed designs connect to both Kawaiisu (CA-Ker-93) and Yokuts techniques.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Grant 1965

Mount PiÃ±os / San Emigdio (CA-Ker-77)

Chumash Â· Possibly pre-contact, though blue-green pigment origin debated.
Rock Surface: Sandstone formations near the Mount PiÃ±os area.
Colors & Pigments: Red, black, white, plus rare light-green or blue-green pigment (possibly azurite/malachite copper carbonates, or possibly Mission-era introduced pigment â€” not scientifically analyzed).
Style: Chumash site near Mount PiÃ±os with unique blue-green pigment. This site sits at the intersection of Chumash, Kawaiisu, and Yokuts territories.
Motifs: Chumash-style designs with rare blue-green coloring. Designs formed by red dashes that resemble those at Hurricane Deck and Kawaiisu CA-Ker-93.
Who Made It: Chumash â€” possibly VentureÃ±o Chumash bands occupying the highest mountain territory.
Meaning: Ceremonial. Located near the sacred mountain Iwihinmu (Mount PiÃ±os), the highest point in Chumash territory at 8,831 feet. A place of great spiritual significance.
Style Correlates: Bridge site connecting Chumash to Kawaiisu territory. Blue-green pigment unique in region.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Lee 1979; Grant 1965

Kitanemuk Village Site (CA-Ker-129)

Kitanemuk Â· Kitanemuk occupation estimated several thousand years. Rock art poorly dated.
Rock Surface: Granite boulders in the western Tehachapi/Liebre Mountains area. Possibly near a major Kitanemuk village.
Colors & Pigments: Not well documented â€” likely red, black, white based on regional patterns.
Style: The least documented tradition. Only four elements, two possibly anthropomorphic. Much smaller site than others. Assigned to 'Southern California Rectilinear Abstract' style (Hedges 1973).
Motifs: Four recorded elements â€” two possibly anthropomorphic. Very limited corpus. Sutton (1982a:31) surveyed the sites briefly.
Who Made It: Kitanemuk â€” Takic Uto-Aztecan speakers. Their social organization resembled southern neighbors but mythology aligned with northern/western neighbors (Blackburn & Bean 1978). Fought with Tataviam, unfriendly toward Yokuts.
Meaning: Unknown due to limited documentation. Kitanemuk rock art stands apart as the least studied tradition in the region.
Style Correlates: Assigned to Southern California Rectilinear Abstract style â€” distinct from the 'spectacular geometric polychrome' tradition shared by the other five groups.
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Sutton 1982a; Hedges 1973; Blackburn & Bean 1978

Temblor Range Disputed Site (CA-Ker-160)

Chumash/Yokuts disputed Â· Likely 500-1500 CE.
Rock Surface: Temblor Range formation â€” sedimentary rocks along the Chumash-Yokuts boundary.
Colors & Pigments: Polychrome â€” Chumash and Yokuts color palettes both represented.
Style: A 'borderline' site declared Chumash by Grant (1965) and Yokuts by Sanger (1987). Illustrates the impossibility of assigning borderland sites to a single culture based on rock art alone.
Motifs: Mixed elements â€” some art closely resembles Chumash, but the site is within Yokuts territory. Likely used by both groups, as were other sites in the Carrizo Plain region.
Who Made It: Both Chumash and Yokuts. Lee & Hyder argue the site was used by both groups â€” the Temblor Range was the ethnographic boundary but also open territory for interaction.
Meaning: The debate over this site is itself evidence of the cultural blending Lee & Hyder document. The boundary was permeable, with people trading, intermarrying, and sharing ceremonies.
Style Correlates: Shares features of both Chumash (scale, technique) and Yokuts (motifs, placement).
Sources: Lee & Hyder 1991; Grant 1965; Sanger 1987

ðŸŽ­ Carrizo Plain Borderland

Chumash-Yokuts interaction zone â€” where both traditions painted side by side at Painted Rock. Open territory for trade, intermarriage, and shared ceremonies.
Source: Lee & Hyder 1991

ðŸŽ­ Tehachapi Crossroads

Kawaiisu-Kitanemuk-TÃ¼batulabal convergence. Kawaiisu rock art shows elements borrowed from all neighboring traditions â€” the most eclectic style in the region.
Source: Lee & Hyder 1991

ðŸŽ­ Southern Sierra Blend

Yokuts-TÃ¼batulabal-Kawaiisu zone. Intermarriage was so extensive that Kroeber said it was 'impossible to assign an exact habitat' to any group here.
Source: Lee & Hyder 1991

ðŸŽ­ VentureÃ±o Corridor

Tataviam-Chumash-Yokuts borderland. Tataviam rock art is so similar to Chumash that experts debate attribution. Vasquez Rocks sit along this cultural corridor.
Source: Lee & Hyder 1991

Creston Pictographs (Steward #95)


Salinan Â· Pictograph Site

Located on a hill opposite the Huer-Huero schoolhouse, approximately 6 miles southeast of Creston, San Luis Obispo County. Firmly within Salinan territory along the eastern flanks of the Santa Lucia Range.

Pictographs in red and yellow on sandstone. The site is notable for many bedrock mortar holes nearby, indicating long-term seasonal use as an acorn processing station. The association of rock art with milling features suggests this was both a practical food-gathering site and a location of ritual or symbolic importance â€” a pattern seen throughout Salinan territory.

The Salinan people lived along the Salinas River valley, encompassing present-day Monterey and San Luis Obispo counties. Their territory included some of the most rugged topography in the Coast Ranges. The Salinan are divided into two main groups: the Antonianos (associated with Mission San Antonio) and the MigueleÃ±os (associated with Mission San Miguel).

Source: Steward 1929 (via Mr. Cliff)

Jolon / San Miguelito Ranch Pictographs (Steward #98)


Salinan (Antonianos) Â· Pictograph Site

Located on the San Miguelito ranch near Jolon in the San Antonio River valley, southern Monterey County. Within the heart of Salinan Antonianos territory, near present-day Fort Hunter Liggett.

Pictographs in black (primary), white, and red on coarse sandstone with arched cave-like openings. Design elements include an acorn figure, possible ship mast (may indicate post-contact addition), tally marks, human figure, sun disk, and cross-work lines. Rock strata at 60Â° angle â€” rapid weathering noted by Steward.

Three mortar holes and fire-blackened walls indicate seasonal acorn gathering camp. The Salinan Antonianos occupied villages in the Jolon area from approximately 450 CE through the protohistoric period (1450â€“1650 CE). The nearby Wagon Caves (CA-MNT-307) contain evidence of centuries of Salinan habitation including shell beads, bone awls, mortars, and fire-scarred roofs.

Source: Steward 1929 (via P. M. Jones) Â· Breschini & Haversat 1980

La Cueva Pintada â€” Cave of the Idols (Steward #99)


Salinan Â· Pictograph Site Â· CA-MNT-256 Â· NRHP Listed 1975

"The Painted Cave" â€” one of the most important rock art sites in central California. Located approximately 5 miles north of Mission San Antonio de Padua on the San Antonio River, within Fort Hunter Liggett, southern Monterey County.

A large rock shelter (16.5 ft high Ã— 21 ft wide) covered with prehistoric white, red, black, and ochre pictographs created by the Salinan people over thousands of years. Designs include human figures, a turtle, the sun, and other ideographic symbols. Natural rock features were incorporated into compositions â€” a hallmark of Salinan artistic practice. Probable ceremonial use (puberty rites). No evidence of permanent habitation. Floor polished from centuries of use. Roof blackened by fires.

This site corresponds to the "Cave of the Idols" referenced in Father JunÃ­pero Serra's letter of May 21, 1773, shortly after the founding of Mission San Antonio de Padua. After converting to Christianity, indigenous people informed the Franciscan priests about the cave's location.

In 1980, Archaeological Consulting (Breschini & Haversat) documented over 360 drawings, tracings, and photographs â€” now housed at the Rock Art Archives at UCLA. Access limited by U.S. Army (Fort Hunter Liggett). Protected by chain-link fence and razor wire.

Source: Steward 1929 (via Mason) Â· Serra 1773 Â· Breschini & Haversat 1980 Â· NRHP 1975

Tassajara Hand Cave â€” Church Creek (Steward #100)


Esselen Â· Pictograph Site Â· CA-MNT-44

The famous Esselen handprint cave â€” one of the most unique rock art sites in North America. Located in a narrow canyon a few miles from Tassajara Hot Springs, deep in the Santa Lucia Mountains of the Ventana Wilderness, Monterey County.

Approximately 250 carefully painted white handprints cover the walls of this rock shelter. Unlike typical palm-stamp handprints found worldwide, these are composed of precisely painted parallel white lines â€” essentially unique signatures of each individual. Both left and right hands are represented, with individual variation in style. White pigment likely made from limestone or white clay.

A towering sandstone formation shaped like a human hand rises 200â€“300 feet above the valley floor less than half a mile from the cave, and likely inspired the use of the hand as the primary motif. The handprints may be connected to initiation ceremonies â€” individuals symbolically taking their places as adults as their handprints join the many others on the cave walls.

Artifacts found at CA-MNT-44 include bone awls, antler flakers, Desert side-notched projectile points, and scrapers. Steward also noted a red swastika painting 2 miles away on overhanging rocks â€” likely a separate Esselen or Salinan site.

Immortalized by Robinson Jeffers in his poem "Hands" (1929). The Esselen (population ~500â€“1,000 at contact) were one of the smallest California peoples. Their territory centered on the upper Carmel Valley and Santa Lucia Mountains. Carbon dating places Esselen presence in Big Sur since circa 2630 BCE, with recent dates extending back over 6,500 years.

Source: Steward 1929 Â· Breschini 1973 Â· Breschini & Haversat Â· Jeffers 1929

Monterey / Carmelo Range Pictographs (Steward #101)


Esselen or Rumsen Ohlone Â· Pictograph Site

Located in a large cave near hot springs in the Tularcitos hills, Carmelo Range east of Monterey, Monterey County. This area sits at the boundary between Esselen and Rumsen Ohlone territories.

Many figures painted in vermilion red. The association with hot springs is notable â€” thermal springs were often sacred locations for indigenous peoples of this region. Tassajara (an Esselen word meaning "place where meat is hung to dry") also centers on hot springs, and the nearby Esselen handprint cave (CA-MNT-44) is in the same mountain system.

Minimal documentation in Steward's survey. Further research needed to identify the specific cave and determine cultural affiliation. The Carmelo Range was contested territory between the Esselen and the coastal Rumsen Ohlone.

Source: Steward 1929
